thread.title_full: Zimbabwe: High Court Judge Orders Zanu-PF MP to Shut Down Illegal Mine

title: Zimbabwe: High Court Judge Orders Zanu-PF MP to Shut Down Illegal Mine
text:
South Africa: Bonteheuwel Residents and Mayor De Lille Trade Accusations 
HURUNGWE North MP, Reuben Marumahoko has been ordered by the High Court to immediately stop illegal gold mining operations in Hurungwe as he does not have the right to mine in the area. 
The order was passed after Marumahoko, through his company, Crevixs Mining Syndicate, filed an urgent High Court application barring the Mashonaland West mining director and the ZRP officer in charge for Karoi from interfering with their mining activities at Kachichi-Piltochry Estates. 
Marumahoko, a former deputy foreign affairs minister, was issued with a prospecting licence on 25 October 2014 to prospect in the area, which is reported to be rich in gold. 
However, two other mining syndicates, Chando Kupisa and Value James, submitted competing applications for mining rights of the same block but were rejected by the mines ministry. 
Chando Kupisa lodged an appeal with the minister of mines, Walter Chidhakwa who then instructed the provincial mining director to suspended operations by Marumahoko until a determination was made on the appeal. 
The mining director in turn wrote to the Karoi police officer in charge to enforce the suspension until the minister judge made a ruling in the matter. 
This directive prompted Marumahoko to file an urgent application with the High Court before Justice Esther Muremba. 
In his application, Marumahoko claimed that in terms of the law, no appeals on mining claims could be filed or heard by the minister of mines. 
Marumahoko also submitted that the decision to suspend his operations had caused serious irreparable harm to his company. 
In her response, Justice Muremba said what the provincial mining director had offered Marumahoko was a recommendation to mine not a determination and that what Marumahoko had in possession was a prospecting licence and not a certificate of registration or mining rights, which would have given him title to carry out mining activities. 
"At law, a person can only appeal against a determination not a recommendation. If no determination had been made by the first respondent (provincial mining director) there is no way he would have ordered suspension of operations pending appeal. 
"In the first place they would not have been any appeal to talk about," Muremba ruled. 
"That they went to commence preparatory work in anticipation of the issuance of the certificate of registration is a personal risk they took and cannot blame anyone other than themselves. 
"The least the applicants (Marumahoko and Crevixs) should have done was to insist on being issued with a certificate of registration before they commenced any work. The application is therefore dismissed with costs," the judge said. 
In November last year, in the run-up to the Zanu PF elective congress, Marumahoko was removed from the party's Mashonaland West provincial 
executive committee and banned from holding any party position on the grounds that he supported the then Vice President Joice Mujuru's alleged bid to topple President Robert Mugabe. Zimbabwe
